p: The pandemic has taught us that politicians and affluent consumers are not at all as unlikely to curb neoliberal capitalism as decades of failed negotiations on greenhouse gas emissions have led us to believe. The main obstacle to behavioural change and political decisions that would lower emissions is that the threat of disastrous climate change is less tangible than the threat of a global health emergency. In contrast to climate change, the pandemic poses an immediate threat to individuals, rather than a long‐term threat to society. An optimistic conclusion is that greenhouse gas emissions can be swiftly reduced without entailing debilitating sacrifices,1 while a pessimistic one is that, for most people, the threat of climate change is too abstract to be taken seriously.
